posts.name: Bake Room
posts.note: From the Bon Appetit website, ‘Oh, yeah, those pastries I got at Methodical? They’re baked at a small bakery called Bake Room, run by Wade Taylor, who sources local grains to bake naturally leavened breads and pastries. Taylor’s morning bun is an absolute masterpiece, much lighter and flakier than the traditional bun, with a top that gets the old-fashioned doughnut treatment, tossed in cinnamon sugar. Eating it is something like hearing Marvin Gaye for the first time. The exterior of Taylor’s croissants shatter perfectly, and his chocolate chip monkey bread resembles miniature layered croissants more than cake, rendering everything I used to love and appreciate about monkey bread useless.’

posts.name: Callie’s Hot Little Biscuit
posts.note: Callie’s Hot Little Biscuit is a snug counter serve featuring several types of biscuits, plus grab-and-go sandwiches, coffee, and tea. Order the cheddar country ham biscuit which contains butter and cream cheese. For dessert get the peach biscuit.  From their website, 'We are more than a biscuit – we at Callie's Hot Little Biscuit know that there is an art to Southern entertaining and we're sharing our best tips, tricks, recipes, and gift guides on our blog. Find inspiration in Carrie Morey's recipes and read about our newest collaborations and kits! Let Callie’s Hot Little Biscuit take care of your catering needs. We supply a variety of piping hot Callie’s award-winning biscuits, southern tea sandwiches, and a range of other delicious and locally inspired dishes, including pimento cheese, slow-cooked grits, French press coffee, and decadent cocoa and cream cookies.'

posts.name: Chez Nous
posts.note: Chez Nous is a pint-sized neighborhood spot with elevated food and wine from France and around Europe in a cozy space. From their website, 'We are a pint-sized, convivial, neighborhood restaurant located in downtown Charleston, which features food and wine from Southern France, Northern Italy, and Northern Spain. We offer a daily changing menu of local ingredients - the same for both lunch and dinner - which consists of two appetizers, two entreés, and two desserts.' According to the Carolina Eater website, 'The brunch menu at European bistro Chez Nous changes every week, but the comforting embrace of the dishes from chefs Jill Mathias remain the same. Patrons can usually count on soft-boiled eggs with tartine du jour or fromage blanc with honey and granola on the list of offerings.'

posts.name: Chubby Fish
posts.note: From the Chubby Fish website, 'A chef-driven seafood concept from Chef James London. We proudly offer fresh, Lowcountry seafood with innovative preparation. Tucked away in Charleston’s Historic Elliotborough neighborhood, Chubby Fish partners with local fishermen and farmers to feature the very best local ingredients. The Chubby Fish menu spotlights fresh catches straight from the waters of Charleston and changes daily.'

posts.name: Clare's Creamery
posts.note: From their website, ‘Hello, ice cream lovers. At Clare’s Creamery, we have a passion for sharing our love of ice cream with everyone we meet. We strive to create a tradition celebrated with valued friends, family, and neighbors originating from these core principles: Small-batch ice cream hand-crafted in Greenville, South Carolina. Recipes made the way we like them (and we hope you like them too). Quality ingredients sourced from the best local and national suppliers. Welcoming environment and prices that are affordable to all our neighbors.’

posts.name: CudaCo. Seafood House
posts.note: From the CudaCo. Seafood House website, 'Experience seafood like never before with CudaCo., Charleston's boldest fish + oyster market. We're bringing the 5-star restaurant experience to your table with the freshest cuts from our butchery, matched by new preparation techniques and imaginative flavors. Let us show you a brand new side of seafood--prepare for your next culinary adventure at CudaCo.' Titus Ruscitti recommends the lightly fried flounder and the Soft Shell Crab Sandwich, which will be hard to beat this rendition. Another fantastic seafood sandwich.

posts.name: Due South Coffee Roasters
posts.note: Hip, industrial-style coffeehouse offering gourmet coffee drinks, pastries, and other simple nibbles. From their website, ‘Since 2013, we have been roasting ambitious and forward-thinking specialty coffee in the upstate of South Carolina. Our sourcing relationships, thoughtful roasting, and friendly preparation of coffee are all in service to you, our community that continues to inspire us towards excellence.’

posts.name: Fig
posts.note: Fig serves an elevated take's on Southern classics with seasonal ingredients served in an upscale bistro setting. From their website, 'Our approach is simple. We have a passion for pure flavor, quality ingredients, and for creating an atmosphere that is convivial, approachable, and a haven for people who simply love food. We source products with integrity, flavor, and soul and incorporate these seasonal offerings into our menu nightly. The result is food that is honest, straightforward, and pays homage to the Lowcountry, a special place we are privileged to call home. However, the FIG experience is about more than just-food. A sincere effort to educate our staff on all aspects of food and beverage culture is the basis for our service philosophy. It is our goal that guests feel special, comfortable, and well taken care of.'

posts.name: Gather GVL
posts.note: From their website, ‘Gather® is a food and beverage-focused recreation and amusement facility that serves as a gathering place for the community. Gather GVL is not only environmentally friendly, it’s family-friendly as well.’ From USA Today Top 10 Best website, ‘As the name implies, Gather is a food hall that wants to bring people together. A colorful collection of shipping containers filled with more than 10 food and beverage vendors and plenty of places to sit make it an attractive destination for foodies of all ages. Sushi, burgers – even lobster rolls – are all on offer at this outdoor space. Locals also love that you can bring your pets on select days.’

posts.name: Girl Nextdough
posts.note: According to their website, ‘Girl Nextdough is a small batch baking food truck serving sourdough bagels, egg sandwiches, and other sweet and savory treats.’ From the Carolina Eater website about Girl Nextdough, ‘Mobile pastry truck Girl Nextdough usually posts up on James Island on the weekends to supply carb-hungry customers with bagel sandwiches, seasonal doughnuts, fancy “Pop-Tarts,” and creative pie flavors from pastry chef Caitlin Schumacher. Look for bagels, croque madames, and more carby goodness at the new food truck, Girl Nextdough. The mobile kitchen comes from former FIG executive pastry chef Caitlin Schumacher.’ Anson Mills tweeted, ‘Girl Nextdough (@girlnextdoughchs) made Reuben hand tarts and benne seed brioche with our grains!’
posts.hrs: Closed Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday
posts.rcmmnd: Anson Mills and Southern Foodways Alliance

posts.name: The Glass Onion
posts.note: The Glass Onion is an upbeat spot serving refined, locally sourced soul-food favorites in a charming environment. From their website, 'The Glass Onion is one of Charleston’s original homegrown neighborhood-based, locally focused, all-natural restaurants. Owner and Executive Chef Chris Stewart opened the restaurant in 2008 with fellow culinary colleagues. It was one of the first places in town to support local farmers and purveyors on almost every dish and drink on the menu.'

posts.name: The Grocery
posts.note: From their website, 'A neighborhood gathering place featuring ingredients from our favorite farmers, fishermen, foragers, and artisans. Opened in 2011 by Chef Kevin Johnson and his wife Susan, The Grocery has always been committed to regional ingredients executed in innovative ways. Operating under a philosophy of respect for ingredients and their origins, the menu is made to harmonize and surprise. Through their canning program, produce is savored and integrated into dishes in unexpected ways across the seasons. At the bar, classic favorites are served alongside inventive cocktails and considered wines. Whether it's a cocktail and a small plate or a table full of shared entrees among extended family, The Grocery looks forward to welcoming you.' Titus tweeted, ‘South Carolina spring is in full swing @TheGroceryCHS. Cornmeal Dusted Soft Shell Crab on the left and Ice Cream with Mint and Strawberries on the right. Out - f’ing - standing.’

posts.name: Husk
posts.note: Husk is an ever-changing menu of locally sourced Southern dishes served in a restored Victorian-era home. From their website, 'Centrally located in historic downtown Charleston, Husk transforms the essence of Southern food. Husk reinterprets the bounty of the surrounding area, exploring an ingredient-driven cuisine that begins in the rediscovery of heirloom products and redefines what it means to cook and eat in the South.' NOTE: They have multiple locations nationally.

posts.name: Lewis Barbecue
posts.note: Lewis Barbecue servers Texas-style house-smoked meats served in an industrial-hip space with a bar and outdoor tables. From their website, 'The first thing you’ll notice when you pull up to Lewis Barbecue are the massive, custom-made smokers, welded by the pitmaster himself. Inside you’ll order at the counter, where John Lewis is slicing up true Central Texas barbecue, cut-to-order. Meat John Lewis a master of barbecue, John Lewis never cuts corners, unless you’re talking about burnt ends, of course. The pitmaster’s cult-like following can be attributed to his unerring dedication to barbecue – from welding his own custom-designed smokers to waking up at 4 a.m. to tend to the fire, he takes his meat seriously. Barbecue enthusiasts have flocked to his pits for years, waiting in long lines to get a taste of his expertly smoked pork spareribs, beef ribs, “Texas hot guts” sausage, oxtail, and his legendary beef brisket.'

posts.name: Little Jack's Tavern
posts.note: Little Jack's Tavern is a classic tavern with wood floors and checkerboard tablecloths for comfort food, cocktails, and burgers. From their website, 'Little Jack's is a spiffed-up casual American tavern, serving familiar standards and a bevy of classic cocktails.' Titus Ruscitti recommends the Tavern Burger at Little Jacks in Charleston is probably the best $17 burger (w/ garlic fries) he had. Some won’t like the price for just 4 ounces of meat, but the beef-to-bun ratio is perfect, so no need to go double for $4 more. A damn fine chef-driven burger, but it’s great because it’s simple.'

posts.name: Queen Street Grocery
posts.note: From their website, ‘Creating savory and sweet Crepes, Hot-Pressed Sammies, all day Breakfast as well as Craft Beer, Unique Wine, and Vibey Tunes!’ Opening in 1922, Queen Street Grocery has been a little spicy bit of everything over the past hundred years. From an Apothecary to a full-blown Grocery Store and now in its modern-day form, The Queen presents the Corner Store of your dreams. Preparing fresh local ingredients daily, QSG proudly presents Charleston’s freshest crepes, hot pressed sammies, refreshing smoothies, and leafy salads. There’s a little bit of everything for you here — pop in and build a classic picnic lunch to take out to Colonial Lake or eat outside on our sidewalk dining. Al Fresco. We also sell local craft beer from the Holy City’s finest breweries and unique wines from the savant that is Christian “CD” Davis….. Available to take home and enjoy!’

posts.name: SBH BBQ
posts.note: From their website, ‘SBH BBQ is a spin-off of our competition team (Smoking Butt Heads) that competes across the country on the KCBS BBQ circuit with great success racking up numerous Grand Championships and winning the 2020 World Invitational Championship. We have taken that success and brought world-class BBQ to Greenville.’ From the Carolina’s Eater website, ‘Todd Smith pulled a hat trick when his barbecue team won the Kansas City Barbeque Society World Invitational Championship with a total score of 708. It included a perfect mark in pork and significant placements in brisket, ribs, and chicken. He’s bested every known barbecue team on the planet, and his small restaurant on Greenville’s Eastside produces competition-quality barbecue every day. Tables fill up at lunch, so grab a seat at the bar or on the shaded deck through the side door. Order the melty pork medallions at dinner or the burnt ends, when available, and an only on Friday brisket burger.’

posts.name: Scott's BarBQue
posts.note: Scott's BarBQue is a longtime BBQ joint offering pit-roasted pork and chicken, plus boiled peanuts, in a rustic old house. If Anthony Bourdain and Sean Brock endorse it, I'm getting there. From the Carolina's Eater website, 'If you pay attention to food media (and even if you don't), you've seen or heard of Rodney Scott. Between his TV appearances on Anthony Bourdain's Parts Unknown, his mother Ella teaching Andrew Zimmern how to pull a pig on Bizarre Foods, his spot on Southern Foodways Alliance's Joe York film Cut/Chop/Cook, multiple trips down under, and any number of articles written about him — Rodney and his down-to-earth personality are known worldwide.'

posts.name: Swamp Rabbit Cafe and Grocery
posts.note: Swamp Rabbit Cafe and Grocery is a hybrid cafe and bakery featuring locavore American eats, desserts, and grocery items in a comfy setting. From their website, ‘Welcome to the Swamp Rabbit Cafe and Grocery! Here at the Swamp, we work to support and strengthen a just and sustainable food system that allows local farmers and food makers to thrive. We do this through our bakery, kitchen, cafe, grocery, and food hub. Our mission is to buy, sell, and cook with fresh, local food to support a sustainable food system and provide a community space where people come together to celebrate meals. We envision a community that celebrates and supports a just and sustainable food system that allows small local farmers to thrive.’

posts.name: Xiao Bao Biscuit
posts.note: Xiao Bao Biscuit is a creative, multicultural Asian cooking, and specialty cocktails in a trendy converted gas station. From their website, 'Select dishes from China, Taiwan, Thailand, and Vietnam prepared locally and inspired by kick-ass grandmothers everywhere. The menu changes seasonally, with rotating daily specials and family-style dinner service. Xiao Bao is named after co-owner Duolan Li and is originally inspired by our seven-month honeymoon throughout Asia in 2009. Biscuit represents the South, working with great people here - local farmers and fisherman - and reconnecting to the idea of comfort food from our childhoods.'
